com.topcoder.util.format
Class PrimitiveFormatterFactory

java.lang.Object
  com.topcoder.util.format.PrimitiveFormatterFactory
public class PrimitiveFormatterFactory
extends java.lang.Object

A factory class for creating PrimitiveFormatters. Each factory method returns a formatter that converts each primitive type into the same kind of information; the only difference is how each primitive type's different size and information content are handled.

Version:
1.0
Author:
KurtSteinkraus, garyk

Method Detail

getPlainFormatter

public static PrimitiveFormatter getPlainFormatter()
Returns a formatter that converts each primitive type into its plain string representation. The plain format is what the appropriate String.valueOf method returns.

Returns:
the plain formatter

getPrettyFormatter

public static PrimitiveFormatter getPrettyFormatter()
Returns a formatter that converts each primitive type into a "pretty" string representation. The formatter returned by this method formats numbers according to the following default format:

int: ##,###
short: ###
long: ##,###
byte: #
char: #
float: ##,###.00
doulbe: ##,###.00

Returns:
the pretty formatter
See Also:
DecimalFormat

getFormatter

public static PrimitiveFormatter getFormatter(java.lang.String format)
                                       throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Returns a formatter that converts each primitive type into a string representation according to the supplied format string. This method is equivalent to calling getFormatter(format, null).

Parameters:
format - a format string
Returns:
the specified formatter
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if format is an invalid format string

getFormatter

public static PrimitiveFormatter getFormatter(java.lang.String format,
                                              java.text.DecimalFormat df)
                                       throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Returns a formatter that converts each primitive type into a string representation according to the supplied format string and DecimalFormat. Either parameter can be null, in which case the appropriate default value is used.

The format string has a syntax that follows the pattern strings for java.text.DecimalFormat. If a DecimalFormat is supplied, that DecimalFormat's number-formatting information will be used to interpret the format string. If none is supplied, then the default DecimalFormat for the current locale will be used for number-formatting information. If no format string is supplied, then the format string used is the current pattern string for the supplied DecimalFormat, or the default pattern string for DecimalFormat if no DecimalFormat is supplied.

Numbers are formatted as they would be by the format methods in DecimalFormat. bytes, chars, shorts, and ints are type-cast to longs, and floats are type-cast to doubles, to do the formatting.

Parameters:
format - a format string
df - a DecimalFormat to use to format numbers
Returns:
a formatter that uses df
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if format is an invalid format string
